newsitem.title: SLOVAKIA: SLOVAKIA, HUNGARY SEE AGREEMENT ON GABCIKOVO DAM.
newsitem.headline: SLOVAKIA, HUNGARY SEE AGREEMENT ON GABCIKOVO DAM.

text.p: Slovakia and Hungary could reach an out-of-court settlement in their row over the controversial Slovak Gabcikovo dam project on the river Danube, a Slovak government official said on Monday.

"Both sides think that there is room for an out-of-court settlement of the Gabcikovo-Nagymaros problem," Magda Pospisilova, spokeswoman for Slovak Premier Vladimir Meciar, told journalists at the end of an informal bilateral meeting between Meciar and Hungary's premier, Gyula Horn.

The countries have fought over Slovakia's decision to unilateraly divert a considerable part of the Danube waters for its Gabcikovo dam project after Hungary quit a joint deal which planned a similar dam at Nagymaros in Hungary.
Slovakia claims Hungary breached its contract while the Hungarians say diverting the water breaks international law.
Both had agreed to bring thier case at the International Court in the Hague, which is due to consider it next year.
"Mr. Horn said several Slovak proposals were sympathetic an that he could see areas of agreement on the Gabcikovo issue," Pospisilova said.
Meciar and Horn met after a trilateral meeting of the heads of governments of Austria, Hungary and Slovakia in the west Slovak spa town of Piestany.

At the end of the meeting Horn, Meciar and Austrian Chancellor Franz Vranitzky, issued a statement in which they pledged to increase cooperation in battling organised crime, illegal migration and nuclear smuggling.
They also agreed to begin work on coordinated efforts to prevent money laundring and cross-boundary trafic.
Monday's meeting was the second trilateral session of the government heads of the three neighbouring countries, aimed at increasing coopperation in the region.

The three heads of governments also reviewed progress made in areas of cooperation in the energy sectors, development of transport infrastructure, joint-ventures, industrial parks and cooperation among their Danube harbours.
In bilateral talks, between Vranitzky and Meciar, the controversial Slovak Mochovce nuclear power plant was not discussed.
But in a news conference after the meeting of the three Vranitzky said he had presented Austria's view seeking the closure of Slovakia's aging Bohunice nuclear power plant.
"Premier Meciar said Bohunice will be closed after the completion of the first two blocks of Mochovce (by 1999)," Vranitzky said.
"I'm not happy about this, but I'm glad the closure of Bohunice is a reality." he added.
Pospisilova said Meciar and Horn agreed to formally meet in Slovakia in early 1997 to discuss further bilateral issues.

These topics ranged from setting up a committee for minorities, to discussing new border crossing between the two countries and the contrustion of a bridge between Sturovo and the Hungarian town Esztergom.

On the question of a new law on minority language for Slovakia's 500,000-strong Hungarian minority, Pospisilova said Meciar had assured Horn that his government was working on an expert level to consider the merits of either amending existing laws, or drafting a fully new law.
